Cuerpo: Date: Mon, 02 Dec 1996 17:29:16 GMT Server: NCSA/1.4.2 Content-type: text/html CSE 457 Syllabus 1996 Autumn Quarter Syllabus Administrivia: Time: MWF 2:30-3:20 Place: Loew 101 Course personnel Prerequisites: Data structures (CSE/326) A good working knowledge of C and C++ programming Linear algebra Some mathematical sophistication (No prior knowledge of graphics is assumed.) Required Text: Foley, van Dam, Feiner, Hughes. Optional texts: OpenGL Reference Manual . Addison-Wesley, 1992. Jackie Neider, Tom Davis, and Mason Woo. OpenGL Programming Guide . Addison-Wesley, 1993. Josie Wernecke, The Inventor Mentor . Addison-Wesley, 1994. Grading: Project (same grade for whole team): 30%+ Project knowledge (individual): 15% Project write-up (individual): 5% Project artifact (individual): 5%+ Written assignments: 25% Final: 20% (A "+" denotes an area in which extra credit can be earned.) Projects: This is the second year that CSE/457 is being taught using our new graphics instructional lab consisting of 14 Silicon Graphics Indy R4400s. You'll work indvidually only on the first project (Project #0). For the next three projects, you'll work with a team of 2 to 3 students. Projects will be graded during in-person sessions with one of the TAs . During the grading session, a TA will run the project to make sure that it conforms to the project guidelines. One grade will be assigned for all members of the team for the project's implementation. A third component of the grade is based on your individual project write-up. This means that the modification stamp on the project executable must be earlier than the start of lecture on the due date. Late assignments are marked down at a rate of 33% per day (not per lecture), meaning that if you fail to turn in an assignment on time it is worth 66% for the first 24 hours after the deadline, 33% for the next 24 hours, and it is worth nothing after that. In addition, no extra credit for bells and whistles will be awarded for any late assignment .
